Who is Affected by Disc Herniation?

 

 Disc herniation typically affects adults between 30 and 50 years old, with approximately twice as many
 men as women (StatPearls, 2025). The lifetime risk for symptomatic herniation is 1-3%
 (WFNS, 2024).

 95% of all lumbar herniations occur at the two lowest levels: L4-L5 and L5-S1. This is
 because these segments bear the most weight and have the greatest mobility.

Describe When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly for Breathing, Stress and Back.

When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly

 

 Dysfunctional Breathing Is More Common Than You Think

 Approximately 6-10% of the general population has dysfunctional breathing (Thomas et
 al., 2005; Boulding et al., 2016). Among asthma patients, this rises to 29-47%.

 Dysfunctional breathing means you use the wrong muscles. Instead of letting the diaphragm do the work,
 the body recruits accessory muscles in the neck and shoulders - muscles that are actually meant for
 short-term effort.

 
 The Vicious Cycle

 
 Accessory muscles overworked

 →
 Neck and shoulder pain

 →
 Stress response increases

 →
 Breathing becomes more shallow

 

 

 
 Signs That You're Breathing Wrong

 
 Shoulders rise during inhalation (instead of the belly expanding)

 Feeling of never getting enough air, even at rest

 Tension in neck and shoulders

 Frequent sighing or yawning

 Fatigue that isn't explained by lack of sleep

Identify red flags for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Numb Arm and Tingling:

Position-dependent symptoms

 A characteristic feature of TOS is that symptoms often worsen in certain positions:

 
 Arms overhead (washing hair, painting ceiling)

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Pust, Stress og Rygg.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan dårlig holdning virkelig påvirke pusten?

 Ja. Studier viser at hyperkyfose reduserer diafragmabevegelse med opptil 35% og lungekapasitet med 0,25-0,81 liter. Dette er målbare, fysiologiske endringer.

 

 
 Hjelper det å "rette seg opp" bevisst?

 På kort sikt ja, men aktiv muskelbruk er slitsomt. Målet er å forbedre thorakal bevegelighet slik at en god holdning krever mindre anstrengelse. Trening og mobilisering er mer effektivt enn bare å "tenke på å sitte rett".

 

 
 Kan pusteØvelser virkelig redusere stress?

 Forskning viser moderat effekt (effektstørrelse 0,35). Forlenget utpust aktiverer det parasympatiske nervesystemet og kan senke kortisolnivåer. Effekten kommer etter noen dagers regelmessig Øving.

 

 
 Hvor lenge må jeg gjøre Øvelser får det hjelper?

 De fleste studier viser effekt etter 4-8 uker med regelmessig trening (2-3 Økter per uke). PusteØvelser kan gi umiddelbar avspenningseffekt, men varige endringer krever tid.

 

 
 Er det farlig å ha krum rygg?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Mange lever fint med varierende grad av kyfose. Problemet oppstar når stivheten begrenser funksjon eller gir plager. En fleksibel kyfose er mindre problematisk enn en rigid en.

 

 
 Bør jeg ta røntgen eller MR?

 Vanligvis ikke ved typiske holdningsplager. Klinisk undersøkelse gir ofte tilstrekkelig informasjon. Bildediagnostikk kan våre aktuelt ved mistanke om strukturelle Årsaker som Scheuermanns sykdom eller kompresjonsbrudd.

 

 
 Påvirker holdni...

Describe Imaging is rarely necessary in the context of Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Imaging is rarely necessary

 MRI and X-ray often show age-related changes - such as disc degeneration or facet joint arthritis - in
 people without pain. A study found that 89% of people between 60 and 69 years have facet joint arthritis
 on MRI without having symptoms (Wood and colleagues).

 The images can therefore be misleading. Clinical examination often provides more relevant
 information than what the images can tell.

 Imaging is indicated when there is suspicion of serious pathology, after trauma, or with neurological
 deficits that do not improve.

Describe most common causes for Foot and Ankle Problems.

Most Common Causes

 Plantar Fasciopathy (Heel Pain)

 10% lifetime risk 

 Go to full article on plantar fasciopathy 

 The most common cause of heel pain. Affects approx. 10% of the population during their lifetime. Most common between 40-60 years. Women have 2.5 times higher risk than men.

 What is it? Degenerative changes in the plantar fascia - the connective tissue band
 that stretches from the heel to the toes. Despite the name "fasciitis", it's not inflammation but
 breakdown of collagen fibres. Therefore the term "fasciopathy" is now used.

 Characteristics: Intense stabbing heel pain with the first steps in the morning
 ("start pain"). The pain often improves after a few minutes, but can return after prolonged activity.

 Most important risk factors
 Limited ankle mobility ( 23x increased risk at zero degrees dorsiflexion)

 Overweight (BMI >30 gives 5-6x increased risk )

 Occupations with lots of standing

 Prognosis: 80-90% improve with conservative treatment within 12 months. Shockwave treatment has the strongest long-term evidence for persistent cases.

 The Heel Spur Myth

 Many think the heel spur "pokes" and causes the pain. This is wrong.

 55% of adults over 60 have heel spurs, but 61% of these have no symptoms 

 Only 31% of people with visible spurs have pain

 Treatment is identical whether there's a spur or not

 Ankle Sprains and Chronic Instability

 19-27 per 1000/year 

 Go to full article on ankle sprains 

 One of the most common musculoskeletal injuries. Annual incidence of 19-27 per 1000 people . 85% affect the lateral (outer) ligaments. Among athletes, the incidence is even higher - up to 11.55 per 1000 training sessions.

 Serious complication: 40% develop chronic ankle instability within 12
 months after first-time sprain if rehabilitation isn't done properly. Among athletes in high-risk
 sports, the numbers are even higher - up to 75% in gymnastics and trampoline.

Describe Forward Head Posture (FHP) for TMD and Neck Pain: Why Jaw and Neck Are Connected.

Forward Head Posture (FHP)

 

 One of the most important connections between neck and jaw is posture - specifically what's called forward head posture (FHP). Normally, the ear should be in line with the shoulder when viewed from the side. With FHP, the head is shifted forward.

 
 
 60-66%
 of office workers have FHP
 

 
 60%
 increased neck load
 

 
 4.5 kg
 extra per 2.5 cm forward
 

 

 Consequences for the Neck

 
 For every 2.5 cm the head moves forward, the load on the neck increases by about 4.5 kg

 With typical FHP, the load can increase by 60% or more

 Neck muscles must work constantly to hold the head up

 Upper cervical vertebrae compress backward (extension)

 

 Consequences for the Jaw

 
 The lower jaw is pulled back and down

 Jaw muscles activate compensatorily to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 Increased risk of teeth grinding (bruxism)

 

 
 Vicious Cycle

 FHP leads to increased neck load, neck muscles tighten, suboccipital muscles compress C1-C2, referred pain to jaw via TCC, jaw muscles tighten in response, increased load on jaw joint, more pain, more muscle tightness, worse posture. The cycle must be broken at multiple points.

Describe Exercise 3: Towel Curls for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 3: Towel Curls

 

 A classic exercise that strengthens the flexor muscles under the foot. This exercise is particularly useful for those with plantar fasciitis.

 
 How to Perform Towel Curls

 
 Starting position: Sit with your foot on a towel on the floor

 Movement: Use your toes to pull the towel toward you

 Focus: Grip with all toes, including the big toe

 Repetitions: Pull in the entire towel, 2-3 times

 Variation: Pick up marbles or small objects with your toes

 
 

 
 Marble Variation

 Place 10-20 marbles (or other small objects) on the floor and pick them up one by one with your toes. This trains both grip and precision. A good variation to keep training interesting.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 50-year-old male with bilateral leg heaviness after 10 km run. Bilateral foot numbness that resolved after 20 minutes. Normal urination. No back pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this is NOT cauda equina:
- Bilateral leg heaviness after prolonged running is normal (muscular fatigue)
- Transient foot numbness = compression neuropathy from shoes/loading, NOT saddle anesthesia
- Saddle anesthesia means numbness in the PERINEUM (groin/anus), not feet
- Normal bladder function rules out sphincter involvement
- No back pain (CES almost always presents with back pain)

Clinical picture: Exertion-related transient peripheral neuropathy.

Safe to treat. Recommend footwear change and gradual training progression.

Describe Supine Roll Test in the context of BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

 

 
 
 6
 Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

 

 
 
 7
 Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

 

 
 
 8
 Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

How is Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis of acute back pain is made primarily through medical history and clinical examination.
 Imaging is usually not necessary for uncomplicated cases.

 What happens during the examination?

 
 Medical history: How and when the pain started, character and location of pain

 Functional examination: Assessment of mobility, posture, and pain-provoking
 movements

 Neurological screening: Rule out nerve involvement with radiating symptoms

 Red flag assessment: Systematic review to rule out serious underlying disease

 

 
 When is imaging appropriate?

 MRI or X-ray is rarely necessary at the first consultation. It is appropriate when serious underlying
 disease is suspected (red flags), with persistent symptoms beyond 6-8 weeks without improvement, or
 with progressive neurological deficits.

Beskriv Hva er plantar fasciopati? for Plantar Fasciopati.

Hva er plantar fasciopati?

 

 Hvorfor fasciopati og ikke fasciitt?

 Endelsen -itt betyr betennelse, men histologiske studier viser faktisk fravar av inflammatoriske celler i vevet. Det som skjer er degenerative forandringer: nedbrytning av kollagenfibre, fortykking av fascien og redusert blodtilførsel. Derfor bruker mange fagfolk nå begrepet plantar fasciopati - en mer presis beskrivelse av hva som faktisk foregår i vevet (Riel et al., BJSM 2017).

 livstidsrisiko
 

 
 40-60
 vanligste aldersgruppe
 

 
 2,5x
 høyere risiko for kvinner
 

 
 83%
 hos yrkesaktive 25-65 Ør
 

 

 Tilstanden rammer først og fremst personer mellom 40-60 Ør, og 83% av tilfellene forekommer hos yrkesaktive voksne mellom 25-65 Ør (StatPearls 2024). Kvinner har 2,5 ganger høyere forekomst enn menn. Blant løpere ser man prevalens på 5-10%, og enkelte studier rapporterer opptil 22%.

Beskriv Når trenger du profesjonell hjelp? for KjeveØvelser og Hjemmebehandling for TMD.

Når trenger du profesjonell hjelp?

 

 Selvbehandling er effektivt for de fleste, men ikke alle. Søk profesjonell vurdering dersom:

 
 Plagene vedvarer mer enn 4-6 uker med konsekvent egenbehandling

 Smerten forverres til tross for tiltak

 Du har problemer med å tygge eller snakke normalt

 Kjeven laser seg eller klikker kraftig

 

 
 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 
 Manuell behandling: Forskning viser at kombinasjonen av manuell terapi og Øvelser gir bedre resultater enn Øvelser alene. En systematisk oversikt (PMC, 2020) fant at kombinasjonsbehandling gå 6 mm storre forbedring i gapeevne.

 Vurdering av nakke og holdning: Nakkeproblemer og TMD henger ofte sammen. Behandling rettet mot både kjeve og nakke gir ofte best resultat.

 Veiledet ovelsesprogram: Individuelt tilpassede Øvelser basert på din spesifikke situasjon.

Describe causes and risk factors for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Causes of Unilateral Vestibular Hypofunction

 Most common
 Vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis - Viral infection that attacks the balance nerve or inner ear. The most common cause of acute unilateral vestibular hypofunction

 Age-related weakening - Gradual loss of function due to natural aging

 Less common
 Meniere's disease - Chronic condition with episodic vertigo, hearing loss and tinnitus

 Head injuries - Can damage the balance organ or balance nerve, as in post-concussion dizziness or whiplash-related dizziness 

 Vestibular schwannoma - Benign tumor on the balance nerve

 Causes of Bilateral Vestibular Hypofunction

 1. Unknown Cause (Idiopathic) - 31-51%

 In approximately half of cases, no clear cause is found. Interestingly, around 50% of these patients have migraine, which can also cause vestibular migraine .

 2. Ototoxic Medications - 12-35%

 Aminoglycosides (especially gentamicin) are the most common identifiable cause. Damage can occur with any dose.

 3. Hereditary Conditions - 17-31%

 DFNA9 (mutation in the COCH gene) is most common in Europe. CANVAS syndrome accounts for 2-5% of cases.

 4. Meniere's Disease (Bilateral) - 2-17%

 When Meniere's disease affects both ears over time.

 5. Meningitis - 5-11%

 Meningitis can spread to both inner ears.

Cauda equina-syndrom - akutt nådsituasjon

 Cauda equina-syndrom (CES) oppstår når nervebunten nederst i ryggraden blir klemt, vanligvis av en stor skiveprolaps . Tilstanden rammer omtrent 1,6 per 100 000 per år - sjelden, men svært alvorlig.

 1,6 
 per 100 000 per år 

 48t 
 kritisk tidsvindu 

 84% 
 har blåresymptomer 

 Symptomer å være oppmerksom på

 Cauda equina-symptomer

 Blærefunksjonsforstyrrelser (84%): Vansker med å starte vannlating, svak stråle, følelse av at blåren ikke tømmes, eller urinlekkasje

 Ridebukseanestesi (71%): Nummenhet eller endret følelse rundt endetarm, kjénnsorganer og innside av lærene

 Avforingsforstyrrelser (62%): Endret kontroll over tarmfunksjon

 Bilateral beinsvakhet: Svakhet i begge bena som utvikler seg raskt

 Hvorfor haster det?

 Forverring kan skje med omtrent 1% per time. Forsinkelse over 48 timer var forbundet med 9,6 ganger økt dødelighet. Det finnes ingen "trygg" ventetid.

Describe symptoms for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Symptoms

 The symptom picture varies depending on whether the herniation presses on nerve roots, spinal cord, or
 both.

 Most Common Symptoms

 Back pain: Occurs in 92% of patients with symptomatic thoracic herniation (PMC,
 2025). See also thoracic pain for other causes.

 Radicular pain: Band-like pain following a rib space, which may resemble rib dysfunction . Occurs in about 52%.

 Sensory disturbances: Numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in chest, abdomen,
 or legs (59%).

 Motor deficits: Weakness, especially in legs (37%).

 Diagnostic Delay

 Because symptoms can resemble heart, lung, or gastrointestinal disease (including costochondritis ), it takes an average of 14-16 months 
 from symptom onset to correct diagnosis (European Spine Journal, 2012).

 Myelopathy (Spinal Cord Involvement)

 In symptomatic patients, about 70% develop myelopathy - involvement of the spinal cord
 itself (Barrow Neurological Institute, 2024). This is because the spinal canal in the thoracic spine is
 particularly narrow, and 70% of thoracic herniations are calcified (StatPearls, 2024).

Explain prognosis for AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

Prognosis

 The prognosis for AC joint osteoarthritis is generally good with conservative treatment.

 The Positive
 Most achieve good symptom control without surgery

 93% with weightlifter's shoulder improve with activity modification

 Many can continue training with an adjusted program

 Surgery has good results in those who need it

 The Realistic
 The wear itself doesn't disappear

 Symptoms can vary over time

 Some must permanently modify training/activity

 Flare-ups can occur

 Factors That Affect Prognosis

 Willingness to modify activity: Crucial for improvement

 Degree of wear: Significance uncertain - many have wear without symptoms

 Concurrent pathology: Rotator cuff problems can complicate the picture

 Early intervention: Faster improvement with early activity adjustment

Describe symptoms of facet joint syndrome for Facet Joint Syndrome: When the Small Joints in Your Back Hurt.

Symptoms of Facet Joint Syndrome

 Typical Characteristics

 Morning stiffness: Worst in the first 30-60 minutes after getting up

 Pain with extension: Hurts to bend backward

 Pain with rotation: Hurts to twist the back

 One-sided pain: Often on one side of the back

 Local tenderness: Point tenderness over the small joints

 Radiation: Can radiate to buttock and thigh, but rarely below knee

 What Makes the Pain Worse?

 Prolonged standing

 Bending backward

 Rotating the back

 Sitting for long periods in one position

 What Relieves the Pain?

 Movement and light activity

 Bending forward

 Heat

 Lying with bent hips

Forklar annen behandling for Kneartrose.

Annen behandling

 Trening er børebjelken, men andre tiltak kan støtte behandlingen
 Vektkontroll

 Overvekt er den største modifiserbare risikofaktoren. Hvert kilo vekttap reduserer belastningen på kneet med 4 kilo ved gange. Selv moderat vekttap (5-10%) kan gi betydelig symptomlindring.

 Manuell behandling

 Kiropraktikk og mobilisering

 Mobilisering av kneleddet for å bedre bevegelighet

 Behandling av stram muskulatur rundt kneet, inkludert iliotibial band 

 Vurdering og behandling av hofte og ankel - noen ganger kan knesmerter stamme fra hoften 

 Ergonomisk veiledning

 Medikamenter

 Paracetamol: Første valg ved behov for smertelindring

 NSAIDs: Kortvarig bruk ved oppbluss, forsiktig hos eldre

 Kortisoninjeksjon: Kan gi kortvarig lindring (uker-måneder)

 Hva med kosttilskudd?

 Glukosamin og kondroitin er mye brukt, men forskningen viser liten til ingen effekt utover placebo for de fleste. Pengene brukes bedre på trening og eventuelt fysioterapi.

Identify red flags for Morning Headache.

Red flags - when to see a doctor

 Most cases of morning headache are due to benign causes. But certain symptoms require prompt medical evaluation. Headache combined with dizziness may for example need extra attention
 SEE A DOCTOR FOR
 Headache that wakes you at night - may indicate increased intracranial pressure

 Nausea and vomiting in the morning without other explanation

 Visual disturbances - blurred vision, double vision (can also be seen in vestibular migraine )

 Worsening over time - gradually increasing intensity or frequency

 Neurological symptoms: Weakness, numbness, unsteadiness

 New headache after age 50 

 Personality changes or cognitive impairment 

 CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES FOR
 Sudden, intense headache ("worst headache of my life")

 Altered consciousness 

 Seizures 

 Headache with the above symptoms may be due to serious conditions requiring prompt evaluation

 Brain tumors and intracranial pressure

 It's important to know that morning headache can be a symptom of increased pressure in the brain (e.g., from a tumor), but this is very rare . Typical for this is
 Gradually worsening headache over weeks/months

 Headache that wakes you at night

 Nausea and vomiting, especially in the morning

 Worsening with coughing, sneezing or straining

 Neurological deficits

 If you suspect this, you must see a doctor for evaluation.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er det farlig at det "knekker" eller "klikker" i hoften?

 Som regel ikke. "Snapping hip" er veldig vanlig - rammer 5-10% av befolkningen - og er sjelden farlig så lenge det ikke gjør vondt. Lyden skyldes oftest en sene som glir over en beinkant. Hos ballett-dansere er forekomsten opptil 90%. Bekymringsfullt blir det først hvis klikkingen ledsages av smerte, lasing, eller følelse av at hoften "gir etter".

 

 
 Hjelper det å toye hoften?

 Vårforsiktig. Ved seneproblemer på utsiden av hoften (GTPS) eller høyt på baksiden av læret (proksimal hamstring), kan aggressiv tøying faktisk gjøre vondt verre. Tøying presser senen mot benet og Øker kompresjonen. Fokuser heller på styrketrening og bevegelighet innenfor smertegrensen.

 

 
 Hjelper kortison?

 Kortvarig lindring ja, men langtidseffekten er dårlig. Trening gir bedre resultater etter 1 Ør. Les mer om behandling.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med hoftesmerter?

 Ja, og det bør du! Forskning viser at trening er mer effektivt enn passiv behandling for de fleste hofte- og bekkensmerter. Men du må trene smart: unnga aktiviteter som gir sterk smerte, og start med Øvelser som ikke belaster leddet i ytterposisjoner. En kiropraktor eller fysioterapeut kan veilede deg til riktige Øvelser.

 

 
 Trenger jeg MR eller røntgen?

 Ofte ikke med det første. En klinisk undersøkelse gir vanligvis nok informasjon. Bildediagnostikk er aktuelt hvis du ikke blir bedre som forventet. Les om MR-fellen.

 

 
 Hvor lenge tar ...

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Athletic Pubalgia (Lyskebrokk hos Idrettsutøvere).

Symptomer

 

 Det typiske forløpet er snikende innsettende smerte - ikke en akutt hendelse. Smerten oppleves dypt i lysken eller nedre del av buken og forverres ved aktivitet. Den bedres med hvile, men kommer tilbake når treningen gjenopptas.

 
 Karakteristiske trekk

 
 Dyp, verkende smerte i lysken som forverres ved sprint, spark, retningsendring

 Smerte ved hosting eller nysing (Økt buktrykk)

 Vag, diffus smerte som kan våre vanskelig å lokalisere presist

 Utstrahling til indre lær, perineum eller testiklene hos menn

 Stivhet om morgenen etter aktivitet

 Funksjonstap som tvinger utøveren til å trappe ned eller stoppe

 
 

 Smerten starter vanligvis på en side, men kan utvikle seg til begge sider i opptil 43% av tilfellene.

Describe symptoms for BPPV.

Symptoms

 The most characteristic symptom is short episodes of intense spinning dizziness (vertigo) lasting from seconds to a maximum of one minute. The dizziness is typically triggered by
 Turning over in bed

 Getting up from lying position

 Looking up at the ceiling or high shelves

 Bending forward

 The episode usually comes after a few seconds delay (latency) from when you move your head. It is most intense at the beginning and gradually subsides. Between episodes, many feel completely normal.

 Symptoms That Do NOT Belong to BPPV

 Hearing loss or tinnitus

 Persistent dizziness that never stops - may indicate PPPD or vestibular hypofunction 

 Headache, speech problems or vision disturbances

Describe causes for Cervical Myelopathy.

Causes

 Cervical myelopathy occurs when the spinal canal in the neck becomes too narrow. Several mechanisms can contribute, often in combination
 Degenerative cervical spondylosis (most common — over 85%)

 Degenerative changes in the cervical spine are by far the most common cause. With age, the intervertebral discs lose height, bone spurs (osteophytes) form, and the joints thicken. All of this can gradually narrow the spinal canal and put pressure on the spinal cord. The process typically develops over years to decades.

 OPLL (ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament)

 Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament is a condition where this connective tissue calcifies and thickens, narrowing the spinal canal from the front. The condition is more common in East Asia (prevalence 2-4%) than in Western populations, but also occurs in Norway.

 Disc herniation and disc bulging

 Acute or chronic disc herniation in the neck can compress the spinal cord, particularly if the spinal canal is already somewhat narrow. Large central herniations are most likely to cause myelopathy.

 Congenitally narrow conditions (congenital spinal stenosis)

 Some people are born with a narrower spinal canal than normal. In these individuals, even moderate degenerative changes can cause myelopathy earlier in life. An anteroposterior diameter below 13 mm is considered predisposing.

 Risk factors

 Age over 50: Degenerative changes increase with age

 Male sex: Somewhat higher prevalence in men

 Smoking: Accelerates degeneration of the intervertebral discs

 Heavy physical work: Increased load on the cervical spine

 Previous neck injury: Can predispose to a narrower canal

Beskriv Hvorfor får man hodepine etter nakkesleng? for Hodepine Etter Nakkesleng - Whiplash og Hodepine.

Hvorfor får man hodepine etter nakkesleng?

 

 Vanligste Årsaker - fra mest til minst vanlig

 
 1. Fasettleddskader (ca. 60% av kroniske tilfeller)

 Studier med diagnostiske blokader viser at fasettleddene i nakken er hovedkilden til smerter hos flertallet med kronisk nakkesleng (Lord & Barnsley, Spine 1996). De hyppigst affiserte nivåene er C2-C3 (36%) og C5-C6 (35%).

 

 
 2. Muskel- og ligamentskader

 De dype nakkemusklene og ligamentene - spesielt rundt Øvre nakkeledd (C1-C2) - får ofte mikroskader. MR-studier har vist fettinfiltrasjon i disse musklene etter whiplash.

 

 
 3. Trigeminocervikal konvergens

 Smertenerver fra nakken (C1-C3) måter trigeminusnerven i hjernestammen. Dette forklarer hvorfor nakkeskade gir hodepine - smertesignaler fra nakken "feiltolkes" som hodepine.

 

 
 4. Sentral sensitivisering

 Ved kronisk nakkesleng kan nervesystemet bli overfålsomt. Systematiske oversikter bekrefter at kronisk WAD involverer sentral sensitivisering med lavere smerteterskler og førsterket smerteoppfattelse (Van Oosterwijck et al., 2013).

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Scheuermann's Disease.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can Scheuermann's disease be cured?

 The structural change in the vertebrae is permanent. In adolescents, correct treatment
 (brace + exercise) can slow or stop progression. In adults, treatment focuses on
 symptoms and function, not structure.

 

 
 Is Scheuermann's the same as poor posture?

 No. Scheuermann's is a structural condition where the vertebrae themselves are shaped
 differently. Postural kyphosis is due to muscular habits and can be corrected actively.
 A person with Scheuermann's cannot "straighten up" in the same way.

 

 
 Will I always have pain?

 Not necessarily. As many as 25% of adults with Scheuermann's report no back pain. With
 proper exercise and lifestyle adaptation, many live well with the condition.

 

 
 Can I exercise normally?

 Yes, most forms of exercise are both safe and recommended. Swimming, strength training,
 running and yoga are all good alternatives. Be careful with very heavy lifting with
 axial loading (like heavy squats and deadlifts) if you have symptoms.

 

 
 Will my children inherit the condition?

 There is a significant genetic component (74% heritability), so children have increased
 risk. Be aware of posture changes in puberty and seek assessment if concerned.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 X-ray confirms diagnosis and measures curve (Cobb angle). MRI is rarely necessary unless
 there is suspicion of other conditions or neurological symptoms.

 

 
 Does it get worse with age?

 The ...

Describe symptoms for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Symptoms

 Symptoms in Unilateral Hypofunction

 Symptom 
 Prevalence 

 Chronic dizziness 
 98% 

 Imbalance/unsteadiness 
 81% 

 Worsening with head movements 
 75% 

 Oscillopsia (unstable vision during movement) 
 22-70% 

 Fatigue/exhaustion 
 68% 

 Symptoms in Bilateral Hypofunction

 Bilateral hypofunction gives a characteristic symptom triad
 1. Unsteadiness When Walking and Standing

 The main complaint, especially on uneven surfaces, in darkness or with head movements. Many describe feeling like they're "walking on a boat."

 2. Oscillopsia - When the World Jumps

 Often the most bothersome symptom. The visual image "jumps" with head movements. About 70% experience this.

 3. Symptom-Free at Rest

 Symptoms disappear when you sit or lie still. This distinguishes bilateral hypofunction from other causes.

 4. No Spinning Dizziness

 Rarely classic vertigo because both sides are equally weak - there is no imbalance creating the sensation of rotation.

 Red Flags - When You Must Seek Medical Help Immediately

 Call emergency services or go to the emergency room immediately for
 Acute dizziness combined with headache, neck pain or recent trauma

 Speech difficulties, swallowing difficulties or unclear speech

 Paralysis, numbness or weakness in face, arm or leg

 Double vision or visual field loss

 Altered consciousness or confusion

 Up to 25% of acute dizziness cases at the emergency room may be caused by stroke in the posterior brain circulation.

Describe Phase 1: Relaxation (Start Here) for Jaw Exercises at Home: Complete Exercise Program for TMD.

Phase 1: Relaxation (Start Here)

 

 1. Breathing and Jaw Relaxation

 
 Sit or lie comfortably

 Close your eyes and breathe slowly through your nose

 On exhale: Let the jaw "fall" down slightly (lips still closed)

 Feel the jaw muscles relax more with each exhale

 5-10 breaths, repeat several times daily

 

 2. Resting Position Training

 
 Say the letter "N" softly

 Notice where your tongue is - against the palate behind the front teeth

 Let the teeth be separated by 2-3 mm

 Lips relaxed together

 This is the jaw's ideal resting position

 
 Tip: Set phone alarms to check your jaw position throughout the day.

 3. Progressive Muscle Relaxation for the Jaw

 
 Clench your teeth lightly for 5 seconds

 Relax completely for 10 seconds

 Notice the difference between tension and relaxation

 Repeat 5 times

 
 NB: Don't use maximum strength - only light tension!

Describe What Happens in the Ear? for Meniere's Disease.

What Happens in the Ear?

 

 The underlying mechanism is believed to be endolymphatic hydrops - an accumulation of fluid (endolymph) in the inner ear. The inner ear consists of a labyrinth system filled with fluid that must have the right pressure and chemical composition to function normally.

 In Meniere's disease, too much fluid is produced, or drainage does not work properly. This causes the pressure to rise. At high pressure, a thin membrane (Reissner's membrane) can rupture, and fluids with different chemical compositions mix. This disrupts the signals to the brain and triggers the characteristic attack.

 
 Genetic Component

 Approximately 7-10% of patients with Meniere's disease have a family history of the condition.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Spenningshodepine: Alt du trenger å vite?

1. Muskulsere spenninger og triggerpunkter

 Omme knuter ( triggerpunkter ) i nakke- og kjevemuskulatur er det mest konsistente funnet. En metaanalyse fra 2022 (Pain Physician) fant at kroniske pasienter hadde betydelig økt omhet i perikarial muskulatur (SMD 1,57).

 Hos personer med kronisk spenningshodepine har forskning funnet gjennomsnittlig 3,9 triggerpunkter per pasient , mot 1,4 hos friske kontroller (Couppe et al., 2007).

2. Stress og psykisk belastning

 Stress aktiverer det sympatiske nervesystemet og øker muskelspenningen automatisk. En studie fant at hodepinefrekvensen økte med 4,3% for hver 10-poeng økning på stressskala. Mange kjenner seg igjen i at skuldrene heves og kjeven klemmes sammen i krevende perioder.

3. Søvnforstyrrelser

 Omtrent 50% av pasienter med spenningshodepine har søvnproblemer (Odegard et al., 2010). Dårlig søvnkvalitet senker smerteterskelen og er en selvstendig risikofaktor for kronifisering. Mange opplever derfor morgenhodepine som følge av dårlig nattesøvn.

4. Sentral sensitisering

 Ved langvarig spenningshodepine skjer det endringer i sentralnervesystemet. Smertesystemet blir "overaktivt" - hjernen registrerer smertesignaler kraftigere enn normalt. Dette forklarer hvorfor hodepinen kan vedvare selv etter at de opprinnelige triggerne er borte.

5. Holdning og ergonomi

 Fremoverlent hodeposisjon ("tekst-nakke") er assosiert med økt forekomst av aktive triggerpunkter og spenningshodepine. Statisk arbeid foran skjerm uten variasjon øker risikoen.

6. Genetiske faktorer og hormoner

 Arveligheten for hyppig spenningshodepine er beregnet til 44-48% i tvillingstudier. Førstegradsslektninger har 3,1 ganger høyere risiko for å utvikle tilstanden. Hos kvinner kan hormonsvingninger også spille en rolle - les mer om hormonhodepine .

Describe types of rotator cuff injuries for Rotator Cuff — Complete Guide to the Rotator Cuff.

Types of rotator cuff injuries

 Rotator cuff problems range from mild irritation to complete tears. Understanding what you have is important for choosing the right treatment.

 Tendinopathy (tendon irritation)

 Most common 

 The tendon is irritated and has degenerative changes but is intact. This is the most common form and responds well to structured exercise. Previously called "tendinitis" (inflammation), but research shows there is rarely true inflammation — hence the newer term tendinopathy.

 Partial tear

 The tendon is partially torn but still has continuity. It can be on the underside (bursal side), the upper side (articular side), or within the tendon (intratendinous). Most partial tears are treated conservatively with exercise and rehabilitation.

 Full-thickness tear

 The tendon is torn all the way through. Ranges from small holes to large tears. Important: A full-thickness tear does not automatically mean you need surgery. Many people live pain-free with full-thickness tears that are never operated on.

 Massive tear

 Two or more tendons are completely torn, or the tear is over 5 cm. These are more challenging to treat, both conservatively and surgically. Surgical success rates are lower (60-80%), and the re-tear rate is higher.

 Injury type 
 Conservative success 
 First-line treatment 

 Tendinopathy 
 73-80% 
 Exercise 

 Partial tear 
 60-80% 
 Exercise 

 Full-thickness (small/medium) 
 Equivalent to surgery 
 Exercise first 

 Massive tear 
 Variable 
 Individual assessment

 Symptomer ved tosidig hypofunksjon

 Hovedplagen, særlig på ujevnt underlag, i morket eller ved hodebevegelser. Mange beskriver at de foler seg som om de "går på en bat".

 Sjelden klassisk vertigo fordi begge sider er like svake - det er ingen ubalanse som skaper rotasjonsfølelsen.

Describe diagnosis for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Diagnosis

 Characteristic Nystagmus

 Downbeat nystagmus: The main characteristic of anterior canal BPPV is a vertical downbeat nystagmus. This fundamentally differs from posterior canal BPPV, which produces upbeat nystagmus.

 Weak torsional component: Unlike posterior canal BPPV where the torsional component is prominent, it is often weak or absent in anterior canal BPPV.

 Diagnostic Tests

 Supine Head Hanging Test

 This test is considered most sensitive for anterior canal BPPV. The patient lies with the head hanging 30 degrees below the horizontal plane, held in the midline. Observe for downbeat nystagmus.

 Dix-Hallpike Test

 Can also provoke anterior canal BPPV, but is less specific. Downbeat nystagmus on both sides may indicate anterior canal involvement.

 Differential Diagnosis - Critically Important!

 CENTRAL CAUSE MUST ALWAYS BE CONSIDERED: Downbeat nystagmus is a characteristic finding in cerebellar lesions. One study found that 72% of patients with positional downbeat nystagmus had central disorders.

 Peripheral cause: Latency before nystagmus onset, habituation, duration under 60 seconds, response to treatment

 Central cause: No latency, persistent nystagmus, no habituation, lack of response to treatment

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Hjernerystelse i Idrett: Når Kan Du Spille Igjen?.

Hva sier ny forskning om behandling?

 

 Slutt på "cocoon"-tilnærmingen

 Amsterdam Consensus Statement fra 2023 - den mest omfattende gjennomgangen av hjernerystelsesforskning noensinne (78 000 studier vurdert) - snur opp ned på gammel praksis.

 
 Tidligere vs. ny anbefaling

 Tidligere anbefaling: Total hvile fra all fysisk og kognitiv aktivitet til symptomfrihet.

 Ny anbefaling: 24-48 timer med relativ hvile, deretter gradvis oppstart av lett aerob aktivitet. Streng hvile ("cocooning") er ikke gunstig og kan faktisk forlenge bedringen.

 

 
 En randomisert studie med 103 ungdommer viste at de som startet kontrollert trening tidlig ble friske på median 13 dager, mot 17 dager for gruppen som bare hvilte. Forlenget bedring over 30 dager rammet bare 4% i treningsgruppen mot 14% i hvilegruppen.

Skriv vurderingsdelen av et SOAP-notat for Krystallsyke (BPPV).

Diagnostikk

 

 Diagnosen stilles primert gjennom sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. De viktigste testene er:

 
 Dix-Hallpike-testen

 Pasienten sitter på benken med hodet dreid 45 grader mot den mistenkte siden, legges raskt bakover til hodet henger 20 grader under horisontalplanet. Ved bakre kanal BPPV ses oppslaende, roterende nystagmus etter noen sekunders forsinkelse.

 

 
 Supine roll-test

 Pasienten ligger flatt på ryggen og hodet rulles raskt fra side til side. Tester for horisontal kanal BPPV.

 

 Trenger jeg MR eller CT?

 I de aller fleste tilfeller er klinisk undersøkelse

Provide a structured clinical overview of Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Sciatica?: Sciatica (also called lumbar radiculopathy) describes pain that occurs when the sciatic nerve or the
 nerve roots that form it become irritated, inflamed or compressed. The sciatic nerve is the body's longest
 and thickest nerve with a diameter of up to 2 cm. It starts in the lower back and runs through the buttock
 all the way down to the foot (StatPearls, 2024).

True Sciatica vs. False Sciatica: This distinction is crucial for correct treatment.

Symptoms of True Sciatica: Classic symptoms include pain from the lower back/buttock, down the back of the thigh, below the knee,
 potentially to the foot and toes. The pain pattern depends on which nerve root is affected
How Long Does Sciatica Really Last?: There's a widespread belief that "90% recover within 6 weeks." Newer research shows this is too
 optimistic. Here's what studies actually show
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. A thorough neurological
 examination can often locate which level in the spine is affected.

Treatment: Danish national guidelines recommend manual therapy (including spinal manipulation) combined with guided
 exercise for lumbar radiculopathy (Stochkendahl et al., European Spine Journal, 2018).

Red Flags - When You Must Seek Medical Attention Immediately: This is an emergency surgical situation.
 Delay can cause permanent damage. Cauda equina syndrome is rare (0.3-7 cases per 100,000 annually), but
 the consequences of delayed treatment are serious.

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?: Here's the good news: the prognosis for sciatica is generally good, but it often takes longer than many
 think.

Beskriv Hva er svimmelhet? for Svimmelhet - Komplett guide.

Hva er svimmelhet?

 

 Svimmelhet er ikke en ting. Det er et paraplybegrep som dekker flere ulike opplevelser:

 
 Tre typer svimmelhet

 
 Vertigo: Følelsen av at du eller omgivelsene roterer. Rommet spinner, eller du føler at du snurrer rundt selv om du star stille. Dette skyldes nesten alltid forstyrrelser i balanseorganet.

 Uståhet: Beskrives ofte som en gyngende eller vuggende følelse - som å stå på et bøtdekk. Du føler deg ikke helt stabil på beina.

 Ørhet: En diffus følelse av å våre "tØkete" i hodet. Noen beskriver det som at de nesten skal besvime.

 
 

 Hvordan balansen fungerer

 Tre systemer sender kontinuerlig informasjon til hjernen:

 
 
 👂

 Balanseorganet

 I det indre Øret - registrerer hodets bevegelser og posisjon

 

 
 👁

 Øynene

 Forteller hjernen hvor du befinner deg i forhold til omgivelsene

 

 
 🦶

 Kroppssansen

 Sensorer i muskler, sener og ledd gir beskjed om kroppens stilling

 

 

 Når alle tre systemene sender samsvarende signaler, føler du deg stabil. Når ett system sender feil informasjon - eller systemene sender motstridende signaler - oppstar svimmelhet.

Hva forårsaker SLAP-lesjon: Alt du trenger å vite?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 SLAP-lesjoner kan oppstå på flere mater:

 Akutt skade

 
 Fall på utstrakt arm: Kompresjonskrefter presser overarmshodet opp mot labrum

 Direkte traume: Slag mot skulderen

 Plutselig drag: Tungt løft eller rykk i armen

 

 Overbelastning (vanligst)

 
 
 Repeterende overhead-aktivitet

 HovedÅrsak
 

 Kastebevegelser og overhead-idretter utsetter bicepsfestet for gjentatte drag-krefter. Over tid kan dette fore til SLAP-lesjon. Vanlig hos:

 
 Handballspillere (se kasterskulder)

 Volleyballspillere

 Baseball-kastere

 Svommere

 Tennissillere

 
 

 Risikofaktorer

 
 Overhead-idretter, særlig kasteidretter

 Alder 20-40 Ør for traumatiske lesjoner

 Alder over 40 for degenerative forandringer (type I)

 Glenohumeral innadrotasjonsunderskudd (GIRD)

 Svak scapula-kontroll

 Tidligere skulderinstabilitet

 

 
 Viktig perspektiv

 Mange har SLAP-lesjoner på MR uten symptomer. En studie fant at opptil 55% av asymptomatiske skulder hos personer over 45 Ør hadde labrum-forandringer. Dette betyr at et MR-funn ikke nødvendigvis forklarer smerten din.

Differential diagnoses for Thoracic Back Pain?

Scheuermann's Disease

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounding) in the thoracic spine, usually discovered in adolescence.

 Abnormal rounding of the upper back

 Stiffness and aching pain

 Wedged vertebrae visible on X-ray

 Can be treated conservatively in most cases

Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Rarer than in the neck and lower back, but can occur. Accounts for only 1-2% of all disc herniations.

 Often asymptomatic even when found on MRI

 Can cause radiation around the ribs

 Rarely requires surgery

Ankylosing Spondylitis

 Rheumatic disease causing inflammation and gradual stiffening of the spine.

 Morning stiffness over 30 minutes

 Improves with activity

 Often onset before age 40

 Requires referral to rheumatologist

Describe causes - the hip connection for IT Band Syndrome.

Causes - The Hip Connection

 Research has clearly shown that hip weakness is a major factor in IT band syndrome
 Fredericson's Classic Study (2000)

 Runners with IT band syndrome had 23% weaker hip abductors (women) and 29% weaker (men) compared to
 healthy controls. After 6 weeks of hip strengthening, 92% returned to pain-free running.

 Risk Factors

 Weak hip abductors: Gluteus medius weakness is key

 Rapid training increase: Too much, too soon

 Running on camber: Always the same side of the road

 Downhill running: Increases IT band compression

 Worn shoes: Over 500-800 km

 Knee angle: Maximum irritation at 30 degrees flexion

Describe symptoms - how to tell them apart? for Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Symptoms - How to Tell Them Apart?

 Both conditions cause pain that worsens with breathing and movement. But there are some important
 differences
 Characteristic 
 Rib Fracture 
 Rib Dislocation 

 Trauma history 
 Clear - you remember exactly when/how 
 Often vague or none 

 Pain onset 
 Immediately after trauma 
 Gradual or sudden without trauma 

 With pressure 
 Extreme tenderness, possible crepitation 
 Moderate tenderness, trigger points 

 Swelling/bruising 
 Often visible after 1-2 weeks 
 None or minimal 

 Breathing 
 Shallow, very limited 
 Can take deep breaths (but it hurts) 

 Pain intensity 
 Very intense 
 Moderate to strong 

 The Main Rule: With rib fractures, the patient remembers exactly when and how the pain
 started - there was trauma. With rib dislocation, the history is often more vague: "I just woke up with
 it" or "It came after I had been sitting for a long time."

Beskriv Hva er vestibulær migrene? for Vestibulær Migrene: Når Svimmelheten Tar Over Livet.

Hva er vestibulær migrene?

 

 Vestibulær migrene er en nevrologisk tilstand der migrenemekanismene i hjernen påvirker balansesentrene i hjernestammen og lillehjernen. I motsetning til hva mange tror, trenger du ikke ha hodepine under et anfall. Faktisk opplever kun rundt 25% av pasientene hodepine samtidig med svimmelheten.

 Tilstanden rammer 1-3% av befolkningen og er langt vanligere enn Menieres sykdom, som mange feilaktig diagnostiseres med. I spesialiserte svimmelhetsklinikker utgjør vestibulær migrene opptil 25% av alle nyhenviste pasienter. Kvinner rammes oftere enn menn, med et forhold på omtrent 3-5:1.

 
 
 1-3%
 av befolkningen
 

 
 25%
 av svimmelhetsklinikk-pasienter
 

 
 7-8 Ør
 gjennomsnittlig tid til diagnose
 

 

 
 Hvorfor blir tilstanden så ofte oversett?

 Hodepine og svimmelhet opptrer sjelden samtidig. Pasienten kan ha hatt migrene i ungdommen som "forsvant," for så å utvikle uforklarlig svimmelhet 10-20 Ør senere. I en amerikansk undersøkelse var det bare 10% av pasientene som oppfylte kriteriene for vestibulær migrene som hadde fått beskjed om at migrene var Årsaken.

Describe three types of snapping hip for Snapping Hip.

Three Types of Snapping Hip

 The condition is divided into three main categories based on where in the hip the problem is located
 External Snapping Hip (most common)

 The external variant is most prevalent. Here, the iliotibial band (IT band) or the front part of the
 gluteus maximus tendon slides over the greater trochanter - the large bony prominence on the outside of
 the thigh.

 The snap is felt on the outside of the hip

 Often visible externally - you can see something "jumping"

 Many can produce the snap voluntarily

 Typical description: "It feels like the hip is going out of joint"

 Internal Snapping Hip

 The internal variant involves the iliopsoas tendon (hip flexor) sliding over bone structures at the
 front of the hip - either the femoral head or the pelvic rim.

 The snap is felt at the front of the hip, often in the groin

 Typically occurs at 30-45 degrees of hip flexion

 Strong female predominance: 62.5-86% of surgical cases are women

 About 50% have concurrent damage inside the hip joint

 Intraarticular Snapping Hip (rarest)

 The rarest variant is caused by problems inside the hip joint itself - most often a labral tear (80% of
 cases) or loose fragments.

 Often occurs after an acute injury

 More clicking, catching or locking than a distinct snap

 Pain is the main symptom, not the sound

 Usually requires imaging to clarify

Describe diagnosis and assessment for Chronic Back Pain.

Diagnosis and Assessment

 In chronic back pain, the primary task is to rule out specific causes that require different treatment. Over 90% of chronic back pain is classified as non-specific (WHO, 2023), meaning no single structural change can explain the pain.

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination forms the foundation of the assessment. The chiropractor evaluates
 Pain patterns, duration and distribution

 Neurological status (strength, sensation, reflexes)

 Range of motion and function

 Psychosocial factors (yellow flags)

 Red flags that may indicate serious underlying disease

 Central Sensitization

 An important aspect of chronic pain is central sensitization - the nervous system becoming more sensitive. Think of a fire alarm system: normally the alarm only goes off when there is a fire, but what if the sensitivity is turned up? Then the alarm might go off for cooking fumes, steam from the shower, or even for no reason at all.

 A longitudinal study from 2024 found that individuals with elevated measures of central sensitization (CSI score) had a greater risk of developing chronic back pain. The proportion who developed chronic pain increased from 26% to 32% among those with high CSI scores (PMC, 2024). The pain is not imaginary - the nervous system is overreacting to signals.

 Do You Need an MRI?

 MRI is not routinely recommended for chronic back pain without red flags. Studies show that structural changes such as wear and tear, bulging and degeneration are common findings even in completely pain-free individuals. Imaging can sometimes do more harm than good by creating unnecessary worry.

Describe Self-Help in the context of Occipital Neuralgia.

Self-Help

 
 Heat treatment: Heat pack on the neck can loosen muscles

 Ergonomics: Adjust your workstation to avoid forward head posture

 Stretching: Gentle stretching of neck muscles

 Avoid triggers: Identify and avoid positions/activities that trigger pain

 
 

 Medication Treatment

 If conservative treatment is insufficient, a doctor may consider:

 
 NSAIDs: Ibuprofen or similar for mild to moderate pain

 Neuropathic pain medications: Gabapentin, pregabalin, or amitriptyline

 Muscle relaxants: For significant muscle spasm

 
 With frequent use of painkillers (more than 10-15 days per month), be aware of the risk of medication overuse headache.

 Invasive Treatments

 For refractory cases, the following may be considered by a specialist:

 
 Occipital nerve block: Injection of local anesthetic +/- corticosteroid

 Botulinum toxin: Can reduce muscle tension and nerve activity

 Pulsed radiofrequency treatment

 Occipital nerve stimulator: For chronic, refractory cases

 
 

 
 
 
 7
 Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for occipital neuralgia varies depending on the underlying cause:

 
 Muscle-related: Often good prognosis with manual treatment and self-help

 Traumatic: May take longer, but often improves over months

 Idiopathic: Variable course - some experience spontaneous improvement, others develop chronic daily headache

 

 
 Many Get Better

 Most people with occipital neuralgia experience significant improvement with proper treatment. Conservative measures such as manual treatment, self-help, and medications often help. For those who don't respond, more invasive alternatives exist.

Differential diagnoses for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD?

1. Duration

 Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

2. Aggravating Factors

 Symptoms worsen with upright posture, active or passive movement, and visually complex or moving stimuli

3. Triggering Event

 The condition started after an acute vestibular disorder, other medical illness, or psychological stress

4. Symptom Impact

 Symptoms cause significant distress or functional impairment

5. No Better Explanation

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another disease

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Bittfeil og Kjevesmerter - Myter vs Fakta.

Behandling

 

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Manuell terapi for TMD har moderat til høy kvalitet evidens for smertelindring og Økt gapeevne. En studie publisert i PMC (2015) viste 81% forbedring i smerteskar med kiropraktisk behandling.

 
 Behandlingen kan inkludere:

 
 Bløtvevsbehandling av tygge- og nakkemuskulatur

 Mobilisering av kjeveledd og nakkevirvler

 Triggerpunktbehandling

 Øvelser for kjeve og nakke

 Rad om avspenning og ergonomi

 
 

 Kombinasjonen av manuell behandling og terapeutiske Øvelser gir best resultater ifølge systematiske oversikter.

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 
 Hjemmetiltak

 
 Varme eller kulde: Varm klut på tyggemusklene kan lindre spenninger

 Unngå ekstrem gaping: Ver forsiktig ved store hamburgere, langvarig tannlegebesok

 Myk kost: Ved akutte plager, unnga hard/seig mat midlertidig

 Slapp av i kjeven: "Leppene sammen, tennene fra hverandre"

 Stresshandtering: AvspenningsØvelser og god søvn hjelper betydelig

 Forsiktige toyninger: Rolige gapebevegelser og sideveis bevegelser

 
 

 Behandlingsforløp

 Norske retningslinjer anbefaler en trinnvis tilnærming:

 
 Trinn 1 (0-2 mnd): Informasjon, egenhandtering og Øvelser

Hvordan diagnostiseres Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide?

Gjor-det-selv tester: Finn ut mer for du kommer

 

 For du bestiller time, kan du prøve disse enkle testene hjemme. De gir ofte en god pekepinn på hva som er galt - og gjør at jeg kommer raskere til bunns i problemet.

 
 
 1
 Sokke-testen (sjekker hofteleddet)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Sitt på en stol. Prov å ta på deg sokker på den vonde siden uten å bøye ryggen mye - ved å trekke foten opp mot deg og rotere hoften utover.

 Resultat: Er det vanskelig eller gjør vondt dypt i lysken? Studier viser at dette er mye vanligere ved hofteartrose enn ved seneplager på utsiden. Det tyder på stivhet i selve hofteleddet.

 

 

 
 
 2
 Ett-bens-testen (sjekker setesenene)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Stå på det vonde benet i 30 sekunder. Hold deg lett i veggen for balanse om nødvendig.

 Resultat: Hvis dette reproduserer den kjente smerten på utsiden av hoften, tyder det sterkt på GTPS (gluteal tendinopati). En fersk meta-analyse viste at denne testen har 94% sensitivitet og 99% spesifisitet for seneproblemer på utsiden av hoften.

 

 

 
 
 3
 Peke-testen (sjekker SI-ledd vs. hofte)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Hvor sitter smerten? Prov å peke på det vondeste punktet med en finger.

 Resultat: Peker du rett på "smilehullet" eller gropen ved korsryggen? Da kommer smerten sannsynligvis fra SI-leddet (bekkenleddet), ikke hoften. Peker du derimot på lysken (ofte formet som en C med handen), er det oftere selve hofteleddet.

Patient asks: "What's the difference between herniation, disc herniation and sciatica?"

Herniation and disc herniation are the same thing - bulging of disc material. Sciatica is a symptom (radiating pain down the leg) that can be caused by herniation, but also other conditions like spinal stenosis or piriformis syndrome.

Describe treatment options for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

Prevention and Self-Treatment

 

 
 Measures You Can Do Yourself

 
 Move: The myth of bed rest for dizziness has been debunked. Adapted movement
 stimulates the balance system and helps the brain recalibrate.

 Vitamin D: Several meta-analyses show a connection between low vitamin D levels and
 BPPV. Supplementation may reduce relapse risk (Yang, J Neurol, 2020).

 Hydration: Drink sufficient fluids. Dehydration can worsen dizziness symptoms.

 Ergonomics: Screen at eye level, avoid forward-leaning head posture, take breaks
 every 30 minutes.

 Stress management: Stress worsens many forms of dizziness. Simple breathing
 exercises can calm an overactive nervous system.

 Secure your home: Remove loose rugs, ensure good lighting, use support handles in
 the bathroom.

Describe Myth 7: "It's all in your head" in the context of Dizziness: Myths Debunked and Real Help Available.

Myth 7: "It's all in your head"

 Fact: Dizziness is a real medical condition with concrete physical causes. That many also develop anxiety in connection with dizziness is understandable - the fear that symptoms will recur can be very burdensome.

 But anxiety resulting from dizziness is not the same as dizziness being "all in your head." A thorough examination will reveal whether there are underlying vestibular or musculoskeletal causes.

Describe treatment options for Dizziness - Causes, Symptoms and Effective Treatment.

Treatment Options

 

 
 BPPV

 Repositioning maneuvers (Epley/Semont) have an 80-90% success rate. Many experience significant improvement after 1-3 treatments.

 

 
 Neck-Related Dizziness

 Manual treatment, joint corrections and specific exercises. Typically 4-8 treatments over a few weeks.

 

 
 Vestibular Neuritis

 Vestibular rehabilitation and compensation training. 4-12 week program for more complex conditions.

 

 
 Meniere's Disease

 Lifestyle changes, medications and specialist follow-up.

 

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation is specialized physical therapy for the balance system with documented effect:

 
 Gaze stabilization - Exercises to maintain focus during head movements

 Balance exercises - Progressive training on challenging surfaces

 Habituation - Exposure to movements that trigger symptoms

 

 
 Most people with dizziness improve significantly with proper treatment. The key is finding the right diagnosis first.

Provide a structured clinical overview of L4.

Why is L4-L5 so vulnerable?: The L4-L5 segment functions as the workhorse of the lower back. The disc here has the highest disc height in the entire spine - approximately 11 mm - and handles most of the bending and extending movements in the lower back. The combination of high mobility and high load makes this level particularly vulnerable to wear and injury.

Who is affected?: Risk factors include overweight, physically demanding work, diabetes, smoking, and genetic predisposition.

Symptoms of L4-L5 herniation: With the common paracentral herniation type, the L5 nerve root is compressed. This produces a characteristic symptom pattern
Red Flags - When should you see a doctor immediately?: Cauda equina syndrome is a rare but serious condition where the nerve bundle at the bottom of the spinal cord is compressed. It affects approximately 1 in 65,000 people annually, but requires immediate surgical treatment to prevent permanent damage.

Prognosis and Treatment: Meta-analyses show that 66-70% of all lumbar herniations resorb (go back) spontaneously with conservative treatment (Zou et al., Clin Spine Surg, 2024). For sequestered herniations, the resorption rate is even higher - up to 87%. Most experience significant improvement within 3-6 months.

Frequently Asked Questions: Yes, studies show that 66-70% of herniations resorb completely or partially. Larger herniations (extrusion/sequester) actually resorb more often than smaller bulges.

Describe treatment options for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for POTS, but most people experience significant improvement with the right treatment. Non-pharmacological measures are first-line treatment.

 Non-Pharmacological Treatment

 
 Fluids and salt: Drink 2-3 liters of water daily, start the day with 500 ml water BEFORE getting up. For POTS (without high blood pressure), increased salt intake is often recommended (6-10 grams daily). Always consult a doctor

 Compression: Class 2 compression stockings, best effect with stockings that go to the waist

 Diet: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid large carbohydrate-rich meals

 

 
 The Levine Protocol: Exercise as Medicine

 Exercise is the well-documented treatment for POTS, but must be done correctly:

 
 Phase 1 (month 1-2): Horizontal exercise: rowing machine, recumbent bike, swimming

 Phase 2: Gradual introduction of upright exercise

 Phase 3: Maintenance with combined training

 
 

 
 Results from Research

 In Fu and Levine's study from 2011, 3 months of training showed that 53% of participants no longer met POTS criteria. Exercise was more effective than beta-blockers for reducing pulse and improving quality of life.

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 POTS is primarily a medical condition that requires evaluation by a doctor. But the chiropractor can play a role in several areas:

 
 Diagnostic contribution: I can perform active standing tests and identify if your dizziness may be due to POTS - rather than problems in the balance organ. If s...

Differensialdiagnose: Pasient med smerte lateralt i hoften, verst ved sideleie og gange.

Differensialdiagnoser ved lateral hoftesmerte:

1. Gluteal tendinopati / Trokanterittt bursitt (mest sannsynlig)
   - Typisk: Smerte over trochanter major, verst sideleie, trapper, gange
   - Tester: Palpasjon trochanter, FABER, resisted hip abduction
   - Behandling: Eksentrisk styrking, shockwave, unngå sideleie

2. IT-bånd syndrom
   - Smerte lateralt, kan stråle nedover
   - Forverres ved repetitiv fleksjon/ekstensjon
   - Ober's test positiv

3. Referert smerte fra lumbal columna (L4-L5)
   - Kan gi lateral hoftesmerte
   - Sjekk lumbal ROM, SLR, nevrologisk

4. Hofteleddsartrose
   - Vanligvis lyskesmerte, men kan gi lateral smerte
   - Redusert IR, FABER positiv

5. Meralgia paraesthetica (n. cutaneus femoris lateralis)
   - Brennende/prikking anterolateralt lår
   - Sensorisk, ikke motorisk

Anbefalt undersøkelsesstrategi:
- Palpasjon trochanter major og gluteal sener
- FABER, FADIR for hofteledd
- Lumbal screening for referert smerte
- Resisted hip abduction i sideleie
- Trendelenburg test

Describe Repetitive work in the context of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm.
 

 

 Important risk factors

 
 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

 
 

 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 The symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are often characteristic:

 
 Typical symptoms

 
 Tingling and numbness in thumb, index finger, middle finger and half of ring finger
 

 Night symptoms - waking up with "sleeping" hand

 Pain that can radiate up into the forearm

 Weakness - dropping things, problems with buttons

 "Electric shocks" in the fingers

 
 

 Why is it worst at night?

 Most people sleep with bent wrists, either under the head or curled toward the chest. When the wrist is
 bent, pressure in the carpal tunnel increases significantly - up to 10 times normal. This
 compresses the nerve and causes symptoms.

 
 Symptoms that worsen over time

 Without treatment, carpal tunnel syndrome can lead to:

 
 Constant numbness (not just at night)

 Muscle wasting at thumb base (thenar atrophy)

 Permanent nerve damage

 
 The earlier treatment starts, the better the prognosis.

 

 Where are your symptoms?

 
 
 
 Condition
 Fingers affected
 
 
 
 
 Carpal tunnel syndrome
 Thumb, index, middle, half ring finger
 
 
 Cubital tunnel syndrome
 Little finger, half ring finger
 
 
 Cervical radiculopathy
 Varies with nerve root, often entire arm
 
 
 
 

 
 
 4
 Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. Provocation tests can confirm
 suspicion:

 
 Phalen's test

 Hold wrists flexed for 60 seconds. Positive test: symptoms in the median nerve area are triggered.

Describe diagnosis for Occipital Neuralgia.

Diagnosis

 Occipital neuralgia is diagnosed primarily clinically, based on history and examination
 ICHD-3 Diagnostic Criteria

 Unilateral or bilateral pain in the distribution of the occipital nerves

 The pain has at least two of three characteristics
 Recurring paroxysms (attacks) lasting seconds to minutes

 Severe intensity

 Stabbing, shooting, or sharp quality

 Tenderness on palpation over the affected nerve

 Pain temporarily relieved by local nerve block

 Nerve Block as Diagnostic Test

 An injection of local anesthetic at the occipital nerve's exit point that provides significant, albeit temporary, pain relief supports the diagnosis. This test can be performed by a doctor and is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 When is Imaging Necessary?

 MRI of the neck may be appropriate to rule out structural causes such as
 Disc herniation or stenosis in the cervical spine

 Tumors or other space-occupying lesions

 Vascular malformations

Profesjonell behandling

Hvor vanlige er fotplager?

 

 En systematisk oversikt fra 2011 analyserte 31 studier med over 75 000 deltakere og fant at 24% av voksne over 45 Ør rapporterer hyppige fotplager, og 15% har ankelplager. Prevalensen Øker med alder, og kvinner rammes oftere enn menn.

 En stor populasjonsstudie fra Nord-England fant at fotplager hos personer over 55 Ør dobler risikoen for vanskeligheter med å stå og gå, og Øker risikoen for problemer med trapper med 71%.

Describe PPPD: When Dizziness Becomes Chronic for Dizzy from Stress and Anxiety - When Brain and Balance Are Connected.

PPPD: When Dizziness Becomes Chronic

 

 Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness (PPPD) is the most common form of chronic functional dizziness. The condition affects 15-23% of patients at specialist clinics.

 
 Who Gets PPPD?

 
 Women are affected four times more often than men

 Typical age of onset: 30-50 years

 Often triggered by a vestibular event, migraine, panic attack, or concussion

 
 

 
 Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society 2017)

 All five criteria must be met:

 
 Duration: Dizziness, unsteadiness, or non-rotational vertigo most days for at least 3 months

 Aggravating factors: Symptoms worsen with upright posture, movement, and visually complex environments

 Triggering event: Started after vestibular disease, migraine, panic attack, or concussion

 Symptoms cause significant discomfort or functional impairment

 Not better explained by another condition

Acute vs chronic low back pain — difference in coding?

Acute vs chronic low back:

- Acute (<6 weeks): L03 — Low back symptom
- Subacute (6-12 weeks): L03 or L84 depending on workup
- Chronic (>12 weeks): L84 — Back syndrome without radiation

Transition from L03 → L84 when:
- Pain persists >12 weeks
- Clinical syndrome identified
- Imaging shows pathology

Error: Using L03 for chronic pain lasting 2 years without reassessment.

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain Rotator Cuff — Complete Guide to the Rotator Cuff to a patient.

You have been told that something is wrong with your rotator cuff. Perhaps an MRI showed a tear, or you have been diagnosed with tendinopathy. Either way, you are left with an important question: what does this actually mean for me? 

 The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles that keep the shoulder joint stable and control your movements. Injuries and wear in these tendons are the most common cause of shoulder pain — responsible for 70-85% of all shoulder complaints (Ostör et al., 2005; Lewis, 2016).

 But here is the most important thing you need to know: Many rotator cuff changes are completely normal age-related changes . Over half of people in their 80s have tears without knowing it (Yamamoto et al., 2010). And Norwegian research — which is world-leading in this field — shows that exercise is as effective as surgery for most atraumatic tears.

Describe treatment options for Ear Symptoms from the Jaw: Tinnitus, Ear Pain and Dizziness in TMD.

Treatment Course and Prognosis

 

 Typical treatment course is 6-12 treatments over 4-8 weeks.

 
 Important About Timing

 Improvement in tinnitus often comes 2-3 weeks after jaw pain begins to subside. Full effect can take 3-6 months. Ear fullness is often the symptom that responds fastest.

 

 For properly selected patients - those with clear connection between jaw and ear symptoms - studies show that 44-83% achieve significant improvement in tinnitus, and about half experience complete or near-complete improvement.

 It is Important to be Realistic

 
 Not everyone responds equally well - some experience only partial improvement

 Relapses are common in TMD, especially with persistent stress or teeth clenching

 Treatment takes time - expect 3-6 months for optimal effect

 Many need maintenance treatment or periodic follow-up

 

 
 
 83%
 significant tinnitus improvement
 

 
 3-6 weeks
 typical time to improvement

Describe Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each? for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?

 

 The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

 
 C7 radiculopathy (most common - 60-70% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C6-C7

 Sensory: Tingling, numbness in the middle
 finger (finger 3). May also be felt on the back of the forearm.

 Muscle weakness: Triceps (elbow extension), wrist flexors and finger extensors.
 

 Reflex change: Reduced triceps reflex.

 
 

 
 C6 radiculopathy (second most common - 20-25%)

 
 Disc level: C5-C6

 Sensory: Tingling or numbness in thumb and index finger (fingers 1 and 2).

 Muscle weakness: Biceps and wrist extensors.

 Reflex change: Reduced biceps reflex and/or brachioradialis reflex.

 
 NOTE: C6 radiculopathy
 shows the most variation - only 47.6% present with typical pattern.

 

 
 C5 radiculopathy (~5% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C4-C5

 Sensory: Pain and tingling in the shoulder area and outer upper arm.

 Muscle weakness: Deltoid (shoulder abduction) and biceps.

 Reflex change: Reduced biceps reflex.

 
 

 
 C8 radiculopathy (~5% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C7-T1

 Sensory: Numbness in ring and little finger (fingers 4 and 5) plus inner forearm.
 

 Muscle weakness: Small muscles of the hand and finger flexors. Causes problems
 with fine motor skills...

Describe Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain for Lower Back Pain – Complete Guide.

Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain

 

 Go to full article on pregnancy and back pain ?

 Approximately 50% of pregnant women experience lower back pain (Wu et al., European Spine Journal 2004). For some, the problems start early; for others, not until the last trimester.

 
 Why Do Pregnant Women Get Back Pain?

 Hormonal changes:

 
 Relaxin loosens ligaments and joints å provides less stability

 Muscles have to work harder to compensate

 
 Mechanical changes:

 
 Center of gravity shifts forward

 Increased curve in the lower back (hyperlordosis)

 Weight gain of 10–15 kg

 
 

 Types of Pain During Pregnancy

 
 Lumbar pain: Central in the lower back, similar to regular lower back pain

 Pelvic pain: Four times more common. Over the SI joints and/or pubic symphysis.

 Symphysis dysfunction: Pronounced pain over the pubic symphysis, difficulty walking

 

 
 Treatment During Pregnancy

 Chiropractic treatment is safe during pregnancy:

 
 Adapted joint treatment

 Soft tissue therapy

 Pelvic belts for pelvic pain

 Exercises and ergonomic advice

Hvordan diagnostiseres Spinal Stenose - Tranghet i Ryggen?

Diagnostikk

 

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Som kiropraktor gjør jeg en grundig undersøkelse som inkluderer vurdering av gangmønster og holdning, testing av reflekser, kraft og fålsomhet i beina, og provokasjon av symptomer ved ulike stillinger.

 Bildediagnostikk - et viktig forbehold

 MR er førstevalgundersøkelse når bildediagnostikk er indisert. Men her kommer et svært viktig poeng: Det er ofte dårlig sammenheng mellom MR-funn og symptomer.

 
 MR-funn hos symptomfrie

 Studier viser at 21% av symptomfrie personer over 60 Ør har stenose på MR, og at 65% av friske frivillige fikk stenosediagnose av radiologer. Dette betyr at MR-bilder aldri bør styre behandlingen alene.

 

 Bildediagnostikk er mest aktuelt ved:

 
 Mistanke om alvorlig patologi (røde flagg)

 Vedvarende symptomer etter 6-8 ukers konservativ behandling

 Ved vurdering av kirurgi

Hvorfor gjør det vondt å kjøre bil?: Tre mekanismer samvirker for å gjøre bilkjøring spesielt belastende for korsryggen
Slik stiller du inn bilsetet riktig: God seteinnstilling koster ingenting og kan gjøre stor forskjell. Her er de viktigste justeringene
Korsryggstøtte - hva fungerer?: Mange moderne biler har innebygd justerbar lendestøtte. Bruk den. Still den slik at du kjenner en mild støtte i korsryggsvingen uten at det presser deg fremover.

Pauserutiner - nøkkelrådet: Stopp hvert 90-120 minutter. Statens vegvesen anbefaler dette for trafikksikkerhet, men det er minst like viktig for ryggen. Ta minimum 10-15 minutters pause med bevegelse.

Etter lang kjøring - ta det rolig: Her gjør mange en klassisk feil: de hopper ut av bilen og løfter tunge kofferter rett fra bagasjerommet. Etter timer med statisk belastning er mellomvirvelskivene mer sårbare. Risikoen for akutt ryggsmerte øker.

Spesielle hensyn: Bruk ekstra korsryggstøtte. Ta hyppigere pauser enn vanlig. Plasser sikkerhetsbeltet under magen (aldri over). Les mer om graviditet og ryggsmerter .

Describe Visually Triggered Dizziness (40%) in the context of Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life.

Visually Triggered Dizziness (40%)

 Worsens in busy visual environments (shopping centers, escalators). Scrolling on screens triggers symptoms.

 

 Accompanying Symptoms:

 
 Nausea (72% of patients)

 Light and sound sensitivity

 Pressure in head or ears

 Tinnitus - often high-frequency

 Neck pain and stiffness - very common! See also cervicogenic dizziness

 
 

 
 
 4
 Diagnosis

 

 Barany Society/IHS Diagnostic Criteria:

 For the diagnosis "Definite Vestibular Migraine" the following must be met:

 
 At least 5 episodes with vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration from 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or past history of migraine (with or without aura)

 At least 50% of attacks must have at least one migraine feature: headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual aura

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

 

 Differential Diagnosis:

 
 
 
 Condition
 Duration
 Distinctive Features
 
 
 
 
 Vestibular Migraine
 Minutes to hours
 Migraine features, gradual onset
 
 
 BPPV (Crystal Disease)
 Seconds
 Sudden onset, specific head position
 
 
 Meniere's Disease
 Hours
 Progressive hearing loss, unilateral fullness
 
 
 Vestibular Neuritis
 Days
 Single episode, gradual improvement
 
 
 

 
 Red Flags - See a Doctor or Emergency Room for:

 
 Sudden, intense headache ("the worst headache of my life")

 Headache with fever and neck stiffness

 Unilateral hearing loss or tinnitus

 Double vision or vision loss

 Weakness or numbness in face, arm or leg

 Speech or language difficulties

 Fainting in connection with dizziness

What causes Dizziness - Complete Guide?

Causes of Dizziness - From Most to Least Common

 

 Here are the main causes, sorted by how often they occur:

 
 
 BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo)

 17-42% of cases
 

 Go to full article on BPPV →

 BPPV is the most common cause of dizziness investigated in clinics (Bosner, BMC Fam Pract, 2018). The
 condition occurs when small calcium crystals detach from their place in the balance organ and end up in
 the semicircular canals.

 Characteristics:

 
 Short, intense spinning attacks (10-60 seconds)

 Triggered by specific head movements - turning in bed, looking up, bending down

 Nausea during attacks

 Symptom-free between attacks

 
 

 
 
 Vestibular Migraine

 approx. 1-3% of population
 

 Go to full article on
 vestibular migraine →

 Lifetime prevalence around 1%, but newer American data suggests up to 2.7% (Formeister, Otol Neurotol,
 2018). The Barany Society has identified this as "by far the most common cause" of combined neck pain
 and vestibular symptoms. Can occur with or without headache.

 

 
 
 Vestibular Neuritis

 3-10% in dizziness clinics
 

 Go to full article on
 vestibular neuritis →

 Annual incidence of 3.5-7 per 100,000 (Iwasaki, Auris Nasus Larynx, 2024). Accounts for 3-10% of
 diagnoses in specialised dizziness clinics. Viral inflammation of the balance nerve causing sudden,
 intense dizziness over several days. Hearing is not affected. 10-15% develop BPPV afterwards.

 Soft tissue mobilization of thoracic region (avoiding deep pressure on neck)

Describe what is piriformis syndrome? for Piriformis Syndrome: False Sciatica.

What is piriformis syndrome?

 Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis muscle - a small, pear-shaped muscle deep in the buttock region - irritates or compresses the sciatic nerve. The result is pain radiating down the back of the thigh, often easily confused with "true" sciatica from a disc herniation in the lower back.

 What makes the condition difficult is that it doesn't show on a standard MRI of the back. Many therefore go a long time with symptoms without getting the correct diagnosis. Piriformis syndrome is today considered part of the broader term "deep gluteal syndrome," which describes various causes of nerve compression in the buttock region (Kizaki et al., 2020).

 The condition most commonly affects people between 30-50 years of age, with a clear predominance of women. Estimates suggest that piriformis syndrome accounts for 6-17% of cases where patients come to a specialist with sciatica-like symptoms (Hopayian & Heathcote, 2019).

Smale BH-stropper

 Forskning fra University of Wollongong (2015) viser at brede stropper (4,5 cm) reduserer topptrykket med ca. 35% sammenlignet med standard 2,5 cm stropper.

 

 Andre faktorer

 
 Lang daglig brukstid: De fleste kvinner bruker BH 12-14 timer daglig. Trykk på bare 9 kPa over 2 timer kan gi hud- og muskelskade.

 Dårlig holdning: Avrundede skuldre Øker belastningen på stroppene og kan forsterke kompresjonen.

 3

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Skulder- og nakkesmerter - ofte på begge sider, men kan våre verre på en side

 Smertene er minimale om morgenen og blir gradvis verre utover dagen

 Synlige furer eller merker der stroppene sitter

 Tretthet i skuldrene, spesielt ved langvarig stående eller børing av vesker
